content: Corn Market Outlook: Exponential Demand growth to offset huge supply in 2024-25
Castor Market Outlook: Declining Acreage for Next Year and Higher Stocks on the Horizon in the Current Year

sections.title: Indian Corn Supply Dynamics-2024-25
Indian Corn Price Review
Corn Arrivals 2024: Fueled by Larger Harvests and Improved Prices
Rabi Acreage Trends Align with Nov’24 Report Projections
content: All Major commodities are aligned with the Rabi acreage trends projected in the November 2024 report.

sections.title: INDIAN RABI CORN SOWING PROGRESS
content: As of 30th December, Rabi corn acreage has increased by 8% compared to the previous year, aligning with the projections outlined in the November 2024 report.

sections.title: INDIAN RABI CORN SOWING PROGRESS
Corn Acreage Expectation for Rabi 2024-25
content: Acreage for 2024-25 is estimated to rise from 2.31 million ha (Dec 2024) to 2.61 million ha (Jan 2025), an upward revision from an earlier estimate of 2.50 million ha in Dec’24.
Growth is driven by a 15%+ increase in seed sales, indicating strong farmer intentions towards Corn and Ethanol eco-system supporting corn cultivation.
Favorable agronomic conditions further support higher sowing activity.

sections.title: Acreage Share likely to go up in Southern India & Central India in 2024-25
content: In 2024-25, Southern and Central India share in Rabi acreage might go up thus bringing the overall contribution of Bihar slightly lower.
Bihar, West Bengal, Karnataka, and Tamilnadu are not dependent on Kharif rainfall and are mostly driven by attractive prices as the corn in these states is grown naturally in irrigated conditions.
Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, and Maharashtra are dependent on Kharif rainfall as the crop is undertaken in rainfed areas.

sections.title: Rabi Corn Yield Projections 2024-25
Lower than Normal Kharif rainfall in Bihar in 2024 (June-Sep)
content: Bihar corn acreage to 35 percent of total corn cultivated area.
Though kharif rainfall is higher than last year in Bihar, yet it is below normal by 20 percent thus affecting soil moisture levels in key corn growing areas in the state.

sections.title: Dry spell persist in Bihar between Oct-Dec 2024
content: In Bihar, Below normal Kharif rainfall is followed by another dry spell from Oct till December.
Though Corn sowing would improve in these conditions, However, yield performance needs to be watched out if the rainfall does not improve in Dec’24.

sections.title: OND Rainfall Performance - 2024 Vs 2023
content: The OND rainfall in Bihar recorded a significant decline compared to last year, leading to soil moisture stress in key corn-growing districts.
In other states, OND rainfall performed better than last year, resulting in improved soil moisture levels.

sections.title: June-Dec Rainfall Performance
content: Rainfall in Bihar declined by 5%, from 863 mm (2023) to 818 mm (2024).
Other Key states, including Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka, Maharashtra, and West Bengal, saw notable increases in rainfall (up to 45%).
Tamil Nadu and Telangana experienced stable or modest changes, with the All India average increasing by 13%.

sections.title: MOISTURE STRESS IN KEY DISTRICTS OF BIHAR
content: The Root Zone Soil Moisture Stress Index in key corn-growing districts of Bihar shows a significant decline in 2024 compared to 2023, reflecting increased moisture stress across most regions.

sections.title: MOISTURE STRESS IN KEY DISTRICTS OF KARNATAKA & TELANGANA
content: Soil moisture stress improved significantly in Karnataka and Telangana in 2024 compared to 2023, with most districts showing reduced stress levels.

sections.title: MOISTURE STRESS IN KEY DISTRICTS OF AP & MAHARASHTRA
content: Soil moisture stress improved in most districts of Maharashtra and Andhra Pradesh in 2024 compared to 2023, with notable reductions in stress levels across key regions.

sections.title: Yield Estimate for 2024-25 Rabi Corn Crop
Corn Production Estimate for 2024-25 (Kharif + Rabi+ Summer)
Indian Corn Demand update
Ethanol Blending 2023-24: Achieving Targets with Significant Corn Utilization
content: Ethanol blending for 2023-24 is estimated at 6.75 billion liters with a blending rate of 14.6%, nearing the 15% target.
Corn uptake in Ethanol for 2023-24 (Nov-Oct) is estimated to be around 6.75 Million Ton.

sections.title: Ethanol Blending 2024-25: Region wise allocation across India
content: For Esy 2024-25, 9.29 Billion litres of Ethanol is being allotted Ethanol manufacturers in two phases or Cycles sequentially in Oct & Dec 2024.
However in 2024-25, more emphasis is given to North, East, and Central regions in the wake of increasing capacities of Distrillers in these parts of India.

sections.title: Corn Leads Ethanol Feedstock Allocation for 2024-25
content: Corn dominates feedstock allocation in Cycle-1 (Oct’24) and Cycle-2 (Dec’24) tenders, with 4.85 billion liters of ethanol production planned.
Around 12.13 million tons of corn will be needed at a recovery rate of 400 liters per ton.

sections.title: Corn’s Key Role in 2024-25 (Nov’24-Oct’25) Ethanol Production
content: Corn dominates the feedstock allocation, with 4.85 billion liters expected to be produced in 2024-25 ESY, making up 52.2 % of the total feedstock share.
In terms of allocation in total feed stock production, Corn diversion for ethanol amounts to 30% which could possibly squeeze the supplies as we move in to JAS 2025.

sections.title: Corn Based Ethanol Demand Soars in ASO 25
content: ASO 25 has the highest maize ethanol allocation at 4.20 crore liters, requiring 1.68 million tons of maize feedstock.
This allocation is expected to put pressure on the 2025 Kharif Harvest during the OND 2025 quarter.

sections.title: Regional Ethanol Demand Shifts Impact Corn Supply Dynamics
content: Ethanol allocation for 2024-25 focuses more on North, East Southern, and Central India, driving higher Corn demand in these regions.
This increased demand is expected to lower Rabi corn outflows from Bihar to South India.
Improved Rabi corn acreages in Southern India may help balance the supply, offsetting reduced inflows from Bihar.

sections.title: Expansion in Grain based Ethanol capacity to help Ethanol blending Program in India
content: The West and North regions lead with surplus distillery capacities of 0.70 billion liters and 0.64 billion liters, along with utilization rates of 87% and 63%, ensuring robust support for ethanol production.
The South and East regions, with utilization rates of 65% and 70%, show strong potential for further production targets to run at optimum capacity.

sections.title: Revised Corn Starch Export Outlook and Seasonal Trends
content: Indian corn starch exports for 2024-25 are now projected at 7.00 lakh tons, revised downwards by 1 lakh ton from the earlier estimate of 8 lakh tons, reflecting a recalibration of expectations.
Maize starch exports follow a seasonal trend, peaking during April to June, with monthly volumes consistently exceeding 1 lakh tons during this period.

sections.title: Egg Exports peak out in 2023-24
content: Egg exports reached a record 1,257 thousand tons in 2023-24, making up 14% of total egg production.
Average egg prices in Namakkal at ₹551/100 pieces in December 2024, maintaining a steady price trend.

sections.title: Robust Starch demand to continue through 2024-25
content: Egg exports for FY 2024-25 are estimated to decline by 15% year-on-year, impacted by tightened import restrictions from key markets like Qatar and Oman.
Qatar has prohibited the import of Grade 'B' and 'C' eggs, while Oman suspended permits for Indian eggs in December 2024, following earlier restrictions in June 2024.
These regulatory changes have significantly slowed the pace of exports, hindering overall performance in the fiscal year.

sections.title: Corn EXIM update
content: India’s corn exports are projected to decline in FY 2024-25, with lower volumes in key months like October and December.
Corn imports surged in May-June 2024, peaking at 218 KMT, highlighting reliance on imports during supply gaps.
Imports likely to stay higher in the consecutive year of 2024-25, in order to compensate the shortfall likely to arise from Higher uptake in Ethanol.

content: CME Corn 1M Futures, prices are likely to witness correction towards Usc 420 ahead of further gains towards USD 505 levels in the coming 6 months.
